**55. Mr Eastwood did not limit his submissions to those relating to the three issues**

**Costs Liability:**  
**94. The Defendant seeks an order for costs on the indemnity basis and a summary**

**95. Mr Eastwood‚Äôs submission on costs was to seek clarification on whether costs would**

**96. Pursuant to CPR 44.2 (1) the court has a broad discretion in relation to costs and**  
**whether they are payable by one party to another, the amount of those costs and when**  
**they are paid. The general rule is that an unsuccessful party will usually be directed to**  
**19**  
**pay a successful party‚Äôs costs unless the court, in the exercise of its broad discretion,**  
**makes a different order.**  
**97. The starting point is for the court to determine who it considers to be the successful or**  
**more successful party having regard to CPR 44.2(4). It must then consider whether to**  
**exercise the court‚Äôs broad discretion to make a costs order in favour of that party in**  
**whole or in part or whether to make a different order. Any decision is an exercise of the**  
**court‚Äôs discretion and will depend on all the circumstances and is, of course, case and**  
**fact specific.**  
**98. The approach is one that requires the court to stand back and take a common sense,**  
**broad-brush and pragmatic approach and determine where the overall balance lies as**  
**between the parties. The court should look at the substance and reality of who is overall**  
**the successful party.**  
**99. If a costs order is made in favour of the party which the court determines is overall the**  
**successful party or more successful party the next question is whether there is any basis**  
**to make an order on an indemnity basis rather than a standard basis.**  
**100. An order for indemnity costs is one that is made where the court is satisfied that**  
**a party‚Äôs conduct falls outside the norm, see Three Rivers DC v Bank of England [2006]**  
**EWHC 816 (Comm) at [25].**  
**101. Not every unsuccessful application justifies an order for indemnity costs there**  
**has to be something more which takes it outside the norm and/or which demonstrates**  
**for example conduct that is unreasonable to a high degree.**

**103. Standing back, looking at reality, and making a common-sense assessment of**  
**the outcome, on any basis the Defendant was overwhelmingly the more successful party**  
**20**  
**and there do not appear to me to be any factors that would weigh in favour of the**  
**Claimants such that the court should exercise its discretion in a different way.**  
**I am satisfied that the Defendant is therefore entitled to a costs order in its**  
**104. 105. 106. 107. 108. 109. 110. 111. favour.**

**Civil Restraint Order:**  
**CPR 3.11 Limited Civil Restraint Orders**  
**24**  
**130. An LCRO restrains a party from making applications in a claim unless the court**  
**orders otherwise. It provides an additional hurdle or step which the relevant party must**  
**overcome in order to be permitted to make an application against the other parties to**  
**the claim.**  
**131. It does not prevent a party from pursuing their claim.**  
**132. In this claim the Defendant (and the court) has been subjected to a relentless**  
**stream of communications from Mr Eastwood which has included allegations of**  
**misconduct against both the Defendant and their solicitor. It has included numerous**  
**repetitive and duplicative submissions and applications by Mr Eastwood. Some of those**

**not been determined as totally without merit have been unnecessary or duplicative.**  
**133. All of the matters I have referred to in this ruling in relation to Mr Eastwood‚Äôs**  
**conduct to date come back into account when I consider whether to make a Limited**  
**Civil Restraint Order. I do not therefore repeat them again.**  
**134. Mr Eastwood has now issued at least 9 applications and made one informal**  
**application. He has sought directions from the court or attempted to make applications**  
**in correspondence on a number of occasions.**  
**135. As most of those applications have been stayed and will continue to be stayed**  
**there have only been a limited number of determinations in respect of Mr Eastwood‚Äôs**  
**applications to date.**  
**136. But the persistence of his conduct and the number and nature of the applications**  
**is a factor for the court to take into account when considering whether to make an**  
**LCRO.**

**permission before being permitted to issue any further applications against the**  
**Defendant.**  
**138. When considering whether to make an LCRO I also consider that the claim itself**  
**appears to have significant problems in relation to liability particularly as Mastermind**

**25**  
**139. Following my decisions on 6 February there are now several totally without**  
**merit determinations. In particular the 5 February Order and the Costs Deferral**  
**Application and various parts of the February 2025 Application.**  
**140. The threshold requirement for a Limited Civil Restraint Order is two totally**  
**without merit certifications. Mr Eastwood therefore meets that threshold.**  
**141. Although the Defendant had said they would be asking the court to make a**  
**LCRO at the end of the hearing they had not issued an application. However, ultimately**  
**it is for the court to determine whether to make such an order.**  
**142. Mr Eastwood was provided with the opportunity to respond. He explains that**  
**he does not consider that any of his applications are totally without merit, and that his**  
**claim is genuine.**  
**143. But absent a successful appeal against my orders there are at least two totally**  
**without merit orders and his additional 450 pages of materials in less than three weeks**  
**which substantially duplicated and repeated submissions and materials previously**  
**advanced for the applications and again included repeated allegations about the**

**145. It is intended to assist with managing his and the companies claims in the**

**a broader restraint in the future.**

**balance but that does not justify the level of persistence and the nature and quantity of**  
**duplicative, repetitive materials and submissions, and unsupported allegations made by**  
**Mr Eastwood. He is entitled to reasonable adjustments which enable him to participate**  
**26**  
**in the claim such as breaks or adjustments to the way in which hearings are managed.**

**Costs Liability:**  
**94. The Defendant seeks an order for costs on the indemnity basis and a summary**  
**assessment of those costs.**  
**95. Mr Eastwood‚Äôs submission on costs was to seek clarification on whether costs would**  
**be assessed on a standard or indemnity basis or reserved given what he described as**  
**pre-sealed orders made by me. I did not understand this submission. The draft order**  
**prepared by the Defendant provided alternatives subject to my determination but did**  
**not pre-determine this ruling.**  
**96. Pursuant to CPR 44.2 (1) the court has a broad discretion in relation to costs and**  
**whether they are payable by one party to another, the amount of those costs and when**  
**they are paid. The general rule is that an unsuccessful party will usually be directed to**  
**19**  
**pay a successful party‚Äôs costs unless the court, in the exercise of its broad discretion,**  
**makes a different order.**  
**97. The starting point is for the court to determine who it considers to be the successful or**  
**more successful party having regard to CPR 44.2(4). It must then consider whether to**  
**exercise the court‚Äôs broad discretion to make a costs order in favour of that party in**  
**whole or in part or whether to make a different order. Any decision is an exercise of the**  
**court‚Äôs discretion and will depend on all the circumstances and is, of course, case and**  
**fact specific.**  
**98. The approach is one that requires the court to stand back and take a common sense,**  
**broad-brush and pragmatic approach and determine where the overall balance lies as**  
**between the parties. The court should look at the substance and reality of who is overall**  
**the successful party.**  
**99. If a costs order is made in favour of the party which the court determines is overall the**  
**successful party or more successful party the next question is whether there is any basis**  
**to make an order on an indemnity basis rather than a standard basis.**  
**100. An order for indemnity costs is one that is made where the court is satisfied that**  
**a party‚Äôs conduct falls outside the norm, see Three Rivers DC v Bank of England [2006]**  
**EWHC 816 (Comm) at [25].**  
**101. Not every unsuccessful application justifies an order for indemnity costs there**  
**has to be something more which takes it outside the norm and/or which demonstrates**  
**for example conduct that is unreasonable to a high degree.**  
**102. The Defendant was successful in relation to the Stay application. It was**  
**successful in opposing both the Claimant‚Äôs strike out stay application and the Costs**  
**Deferral Application. The Claimants relied on the indulgence of the court to obtain**  
**relief from sanctions in relation to the unless order that they had failed to comply with.**  
**Finally in relation to the February Application although not every part of it was**  
**dismissed or certified as totally without merit the Claimants did not obtain any of the**  
**relief they sought, and the Defendant was by contrast clearly the more successful party**  
**in relation to it.**  
**103. Standing back, looking at reality, and making a common-sense assessment of**  
**the outcome, on any basis the Defendant was overwhelmingly the more successful party**  
**20**  
**and there do not appear to me to be any factors that would weigh in favour of the**  
**Claimants such that the court should exercise its discretion in a different way.**  
**I am satisfied that the Defendant is therefore entitled to a costs order in its**  
**104. 105. 106. 107. 108. 109. 110. 111. favour.**  
**The next question is what the basis of the costs order should be ‚Äì standard basis**  
**or indemnity basis.**  
**When considering whether the Defendant is entitled to an indemnity costs order**  
**it is important not to conflate the broader issue of conduct in relation to the claim as a**  
**whole when it has not yet been determined and the conduct in relation to the**  
**applications determined at the hearing on 6 February.**  
**For these purposes, the court has to consider whether the Claimants conduct in**  
**relation to these applications was outside the norm and/or unreasonable to a high**  
**degree.**

**116. I consider the overriding objective and the need to deal with cases justly and**

**123. Mr Eastwood‚Äôs submissions in relation to court fees make it clear that he does**

**23**

**130. An LCRO restrains a party from making applications in a claim unless the court**  
**orders otherwise. It provides an additional hurdle or step which the relevant party must**  
**overcome in order to be permitted to make an application against the other parties to**

**applications to date.**  
**136. But the persistence of his conduct and the number and nature of the applications**  
**is a factor for the court to take into account when considering whether to make an**

**permission before being permitted to issue any further applications against the**  
**Defendant.**  
**138. When considering whether to make an LCRO I also consider that the claim itself**

**25**  
**139. Following my decisions on 6 February there are now several totally without**  
**merit determinations. In particular the 5 February Order and the Costs Deferral**

**without merit certifications. Mr Eastwood therefore meets that threshold.**  
**141. Although the Defendant had said they would be asking the court to make a**  
**LCRO at the end of the hearing they had not issued an application. However, ultimately**  
**it is for the court to determine whether to make such an order.**  
**142. Mr Eastwood was provided with the opportunity to respond. He explains that**  
**he does not consider that any of his applications are totally without merit, and that his**

**143. But absent a successful appeal against my orders there are at least two totally**

**145. It is intended to assist with managing his and the companies claims in the**

** Subject: Response to Court's Feedback on Claim - Claim No: BL-2024-001089**  
** Dear Master Kaye**  
** Thank you for your communication regarding my claim for relief against forfeiture.**  
** I understand the points raised and would like to address them comprehensively:**  
** Jurisdiction and Court Selection**  
** While forfeiture claims are typically issued in the County Court, this case has**  
** proceeded in the High Court due to the substantial value of the claims involved and**  
** the complexity of the intellectual property matters. Under the Civil Procedure Rules**  
** (CPR) and particularly referencing the High Court and County Courts Jurisdiction**  
** Order 1991, the High Court is better equipped to handle intricate legal issues and**  
** significant financial stakes present in this case, ensuring a thorough and just**  
** examination.**  
** Furthermore, the proceedings related to this case, including the application for an**  
** injunction and the counter-injunction, are currently under appeal in the Court of**  
** Appeal. Maintaining the continuity and context of these proceedings within the**  
** High Court is crucial for ensuring a fair and just resolution**  
** Exceptional Circumstances**  
** In accordance with Practice Direction 55A, Section 1.3, there are exceptional**  
** circumstances justifying this case being held in the High Court:**  
** 1.**  
** Complicated Disputes of Fact : The Defendant claims they forfeited the**  
** lease on 10th December 2023, but various communications up until the 27th**  
** April 2024 indicate that the lease was not unequivocally forfeited, creating**  
** a complicated factual dispute. This aligns with Segal Securities Ltd v**  
** Thoseby [1963] , where misleading actions by the landlord can invalidate**  
** the reentry.**  
** Mastermind Promotion Ltd - Company No: 09705191 - Tel: 0207 692 8785 - Email: info@mastermindpromotion.com**  
** Registered Office: 124 City Road, London, EC1V 2NX - Postal Address: Flat 100, Watermans Quay, William Morris Way,**  
** London, SW6 2UW 2. Claims Against Trespassers : The Defendant did not issue a Section 146**  
** notice, and the peaceable entry was unjustified as the lease appeared active.**  
** The new tenant, who claims ownership of my unlawfully sold property, is**  
** effectively trespassing, requiring immediate determination to prevent**  
** serious harm to persons or property. As demonstrated in Pineport Ltd v**  
** Grangeglen Ltd [2016] EWHC 1318 (Ch) which highlights the**  
** requirement for landlords to act reasonably, allowing remedy and providing**  
** proper notice before forfeiture, even when rent is in arrears.**  
** 3.**  
** Substantial Value of Claims : The property and financial claims are**  
** substantial, including intellectual property valued at over ¬£2,000,000 and**  
** loss of investment of ¬£600,000. The complexity and high stakes involved**  
** necessitate High Court jurisdiction to ensure just and equitable resolution,**  
** as highlighted in Akici v LR Butlin Ltd [2005] EWCA Civ 1296 where**  
** similarly continuous actions indicating the lease is still active, such as**  
** ongoing negotiations or misleading communications, can invalidate a**  
** forfeiture.**  
** Form and Procedural Compliance**  
** I appreciate the guidance regarding CPR 55, PD55A, and form N5A. I have now**  
** completed the N5A form as required and attached it to this response for your**  
** consideration. I respectfully request permission to issue the correct form for the**  
** relief against forfeiture application with its particulars of claim while retaining the**  
** current N244 application. This is necessary because I am not only seeking to prove**  
** the forfeiture unlawful and reinstate the lease but also seeking judgment on the**  
** unlawful sale of my property. Given the substantial claims for damages and the**  
** intricate nature of the intellectual property issues, I request that this application**  
** remains within the jurisdiction of the High Court to ensure appropriate handling and**  
** adjudication.**  
** Party to the Lease**  
** Although the claim was issued in my name as a sole trader, this was done following**  
** advice from the High Court to ensure I could access Help with Fees and obtain**  
** justice, given that the businesses have ceased trading and they are acting as sole**  
** traders. I acknowledge that I am not a direct party to the lease; however, I am the**  
** sole director of the leaseholder, and my involvement is critical due to my role in the**  
** business operations and the substantial personal and business losses incurred. This**  
** approach is supported by the Court‚Äôs equitable jurisdiction in handling complex**  
** corporate structures and ensuring justice.**  
** Mastermind Promotion Ltd - Company No: 09705191 - Tel: 0207 692 8785 - Email: info@mastermindpromotion.com**  
** Registered Office: 124 City Road, London, EC1V 2NX - Postal Address: Flat 100, Watermans Quay, William Morris Way,**  
** London, SW6 2UW Nature of the Application**  
** The primary intent of the application is to seek relief against forfeiture and address**  
** the unlawful actions leading to claimed forfeiture which we do not feel was ever**  
** inacted. Given that the property has been re-let to a third party during an active**  
** dispute, active tenancy, who purchased all of my business assets and property**  
** unlawfully, the fact that there is a third party in the property prejudiced my**  
** injunction application. Therefore, direct reinstatement of the lease may not be**  
** possible. Thus, I have also sought permission to file claims for damages resulting**  
** from the unlawful forfeiture, including loss of property, intellectual property,**  
** business disruption, and financial losses. This approach aligns with the court's**  
** equitable powers to grant relief and compensate for unjust actions. Alternatively, if**  
** reinstating the lease is not possible, if the court prefers rather than grant permission**  
** to file damages claims, a subsequent damages hearing could be granted.**  
** Complexity and Value of Claims**  
** The claims involved are of significant value and complexity, particularly concerning**  
** intellectual property valued at over ¬£2,000,000, loss of investment of ¬£600,000,**  
** emotional distress, reputation damage, and business disruption. These matters**  
** necessitate adjudication by the High Court to ensure a thorough and just**  
** examination of all aspects involved.**  
** Procedural Fairness and ADHD Consideration**  
** As a litigant in person with ADHD, I have endeavoured to comply with procedural**  
** requirements to the best of my ability. Procedural oversights may occur due to my**  
** condition, and I have requested reasonable accommodations on the N244**  
** application. I am actively seeking legal representation through Advocate to support**  
** me during the hearings. Your understanding and consideration of these factors in**  
** ensuring access to justice would be greatly appreciated.**  
** Given these points, I respectfully request that the High Court retains jurisdiction**  
** over this matter and that the application be processed as a relief against forfeiture**  
** claim alongside the N244 application. Should there be any additional procedural**  
** adjustments required, I am willing to comply promptly to ensure the matter**  
** proceeds correctly.**

**Why the point is legally novel**  
*** Current law draws a bright line: only natural persons (and some social-security appellants) qualify for Help-With-Fees; companies must pay up-front, irrespective of fault.**  
*** The Unison principle (fees must not ‚Äúmake enforcing rights practically impossible‚Äù) has never been applied to corporate impecuniosity caused by an opponent‚Äôs alleged tort or breach of lease.**  
*** Your case brings together:**  
**    * Article 6 ‚Äúeffective access to court‚Äù**  
**    * The company-as-alter-ego argument for one-person companies**  
**    * Causation: impecuniosity said to be a direct consequence of the defendant‚Äôs unlawful forfeiture**  
**No reported authority has yet said that those three elements, taken together, can justify waiving or deferring High-Court fees for a corporate claimant. That is why the Court of Appeal could treat it as a question of wider public importance.**  
  
**Real-world effects if the CA/Supreme Court accepts the argument**  
**1. Micro-business litigation opens up**  
**    * Sole-director companies hit by fraud, wrongful eviction, IP theft, etc., would no longer be shut out just because the misconduct wiped out their cash flow.**  
**2. Pressure to create a ‚Äúcorporate remission‚Äù track**  
**    * HMCTS would almost certainly have to design a Form EX160-C-company and internal guidance for assessing ‚Äúdefendant-caused impecuniosity‚Äù.**  
**3. Knock-on to security-for-costs jurisprudence**  
**    * Defendants routinely obtain security from impecunious companies: that rule (CPR 25.13) might need re-balancing where the impecuniosity is their fault.**  
**4. Litigation-funding market**  
**    * A clear remission route could make small commercial claims more fundable, because the first cash hurdle (issue fee) would drop from ¬£10 k (for a ¬£200 k claim) to ¬£0.**  
**5. Equality-of-arms & disability**  
**    * The judgment could emphasise that fee rules must be read alongside PD 1A (Equal Treatment) and the Equality Act when the controlling mind of the company is a disabled litigant-in-person.**

*** Evidence threshold is high ‚Äì you would still need to prove, on appeal, that the sole or dominant cause of the company‚Äôs insolvency was the Defendant‚Äôs conduct, not general trading risk.**  
*** Risk of opening the flood-gates ‚Äì the Court of Appeal could craft a narrow ruling (‚Äúconfined to cases of wrongful forfeiture causing complete shut-down‚Äù) to stop routine commercial litigants claiming remission.**  
*** Costs shifting stays in place ‚Äì even if fees are waived, a losing company still faces an adverse-costs order. The decision would not abolish that risk.**  
  
**Bottom line**  
**At High-Court level it helps mainly you;‚Ä®At Court-of-Appeal level it would become a useful new defence against fee barriers for a small class of impecunious, one-person companies;‚Ä®At Supreme-Court level it could rewrite the Help-With-Fees landscape in the same way Unison rewrote tribunal-fees policy.**

**1.2 This Witness Statement supports my urgent ex parte application to stay the sealing or enforcement of an Order dated 6th February 2025, which effectively blocks my right to default judgment‚Äîeven though the Defendant failed to file any Defence by the CPR 15.2 deadline.**  
**1.3 Relief Sought: A short interim stay preventing that challenged Order from taking effect until a proper hearing can address (i) the procedural unfairness and my pending complaint, and (ii) my undisputed right to default judgment under CPR 12. **Dismiss or overshadow my pending default judgment application; and**  
**Restrict my ability to file further applications without permission (a civil restraint component).**

**3. ADHD & LACK OF REASONABLE ADJUSTMENTS**  
**3.1 ADHD Diagnosis: I have ADHD, which substantially impacts my executive functioning, organisational capacity, and handling of complex litigation tasks under tight deadlines. The Equality Act 2010 classifies ADHD as a disability, requiring reasonable adjustments to avoid disadvantage.**

**No extended deadlines or simplified routes were offered, even though the Defendant has not defended at all.**

**CPR 1.1 (the Overriding Objective), which demands a fair procedure and equal footing for parties‚Äîparticularly a disabled/ unrepresented litigant;**

**4.2 Bullet Summary of Key Irregularities:**

**Dear Master Kaye**  
**I am writing as Mr. Eastwood's consultant psychiatrist, having known him for a few years in the course**  
**of diagnosing his ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder), and subsequent treatment. Most**  
**recently, we met to review progress at Schoen Clinic Chelsea on 5 November 2024. The purpose of**  
**this letter is to verify his diagnosis for the purpose of his court hearing and outline a range of**  
**reasonable adjustments that may be worthy of consideration, in order to achieve a productive hearing**  
**for all concerned.**  
**There are aspects of Mr. Eastwood's Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) which are likely**  
**to present some challenges and directly impact his ability to manage the demands of legal**  
**proceedings. Broadly, ADHD is recognised to affect executive functioning, including planning,**  
**organisation, time management, and information processing. He is concerned that without**  
**reasonable adjustments, there is a risk that he may be unable to fully and fairly participate in these**  
**proceedings.**  
**Specific adjustments that would assist in engaging with the case more effectively include:**  
**- Breaking down complex instructions into smaller, manageable steps, and offering guidance one point**  
**at a time**  
**- Providing an overview of the hearing at the start, as well as short breaks after each section of the**  
**hearing or prior to him making decisions, to assist him in processing the information and participating**  
**more effectively**  
**- Reminders of his ability to adjourn**  
**Please note that in a crisis outside office hours, urgent support can be contacted via your GP, A&E department or local mental health crisis**  
**/ home treatment team ‚Äì see www.nhs.uk for emergency services near you.**  
**For more detailed information regarding medication please see: https://www.choiceandmedication.org/schoenclinicchelsea**  
**- Exercising discretion to allow flexibility with deadlines without the additional administrative burden**  
**of applying for extensions**  
**- Focusing on the substance of his arguments rather than penalising him for any formatting and**  
**presentation issues in his written submissions**  
**- Allowing him extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings and avoiding rushing responses**  
**- Providing clear explanations of legal terms and ensuring he understands important points before**  
**moving on**  
**- Showing patience in addressing behaviours such as losing focus, becoming easily distracted, or**  
**exhibiting impulsive behaviour such as speaking out of turn, and gently reminding him of courtroom**  
**protocols where necessary**  
**- Allowing flexible timeframes where possible to allow him to stay on task and manage the various**  
**demands of the case**  
**- Allowing extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings**  
**- Simplifying legal instructions and providing them in both verbal and written formats**  
**- Allowing him to present his argument with minimal interruptions to help avoid cognitive overload**  
**- Breaking longer hearings into shorter, manageable sessions if appropriate**  
**I appreciate that these are likely to be aspects of standard practice within your court, but hopefully**  
**having them explicitly outlined along with the rationale behind them is helpful in the interest of**  
**progressing the case as smoothly as possible. Mr Eastwood reports that for over 10 years, he relied**  
**on a Personal Assistant (PA / EA) and other support staff to help manage his professional and personal**  
**responsibilities, as an essential part of his compensatory strategies. This administrative support**  
**allowed him to delegate organisational tasks and focus on high-level decision-making, though due to**  
**recent circumstances is no longer available to him, meaning that he faces additional challenges in**  
**organising legal documents, meeting deadlines, and managing the overall demands of self-**  
**representation.**

**I am writing as Mr. Eastwood's consultant psychiatrist, having known him for a few years in the course**  
**of diagnosing his ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder), and subsequent treatment. Most**  
**recently, we met to review progress at Schoen Clinic Chelsea on 5 November 2024. The purpose of**  
**this letter is to verify his diagnosis for the purpose of his court hearing and outline a range of**  
**reasonable adjustments that may be worthy of consideration, in order to achieve a productive hearing**  
**for all concerned.**  
**There are aspects of Mr. Eastwood's Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) which are likely**  
**to present some challenges and directly impact his ability to manage the demands of legal**  
**proceedings. Broadly, ADHD is recognised to affect executive functioning, including planning,**  
**organisation, time management, and information processing. He is concerned that without**  
**reasonable adjustments, there is a risk that he may be unable to fully and fairly participate in these**  
**proceedings.**  
**Specific adjustments that would assist in engaging with the case more effectively include:**  
**- Breaking down complex instructions into smaller, manageable steps, and offering guidance one point**  
**at a time**  
**- Providing an overview of the hearing at the start, as well as short breaks after each section of the**  
**hearing or prior to him making decisions, to assist him in processing the information and participating**  
**more effectively**  
**- Reminders of his ability to adjourn**  
**Please note that in a crisis outside office hours, urgent support can be contacted via your GP, A&E department or local mental health crisis**  
**/ home treatment team ‚Äì see www.nhs.uk for emergency services near you.**  
**For more detailed information regarding medication please see: https://www.choiceandmedication.org/schoenclinicchelsea**  
**- Exercising discretion to allow flexibility with deadlines without the additional administrative burden**  
**of applying for extensions**  
**- Focusing on the substance of his arguments rather than penalising him for any formatting and**  
**presentation issues in his written submissions**  
**- Allowing him extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings and avoiding rushing responses**  
**- Providing clear explanations of legal terms and ensuring he understands important points before**  
**moving on**  
**- Showing patience in addressing behaviours such as losing focus, becoming easily distracted, or**  
**exhibiting impulsive behaviour such as speaking out of turn, and gently reminding him of courtroom**  
**protocols where necessary**  
**- Allowing flexible timeframes where possible to allow him to stay on task and manage the various**  
**demands of the case**  
**- Allowing extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings**  
**- Simplifying legal instructions and providing them in both verbal and written formats**  
**- Allowing him to present his argument with minimal interruptions to help avoid cognitive overload**  
**- Breaking longer hearings into shorter, manageable sessions if appropriate**  
**I appreciate that these are likely to be aspects of standard practice within your court, but hopefully**  
**having them explicitly outlined along with the rationale behind them is helpful in the interest of**  
**progressing the case as smoothly as possible. Mr Eastwood reports that for over 10 years, he relied**  
**on a Personal Assistant (PA / EA) and other support staff to help manage his professional and personal**  
**responsibilities, as an essential part of his compensatory strategies. This administrative support**  
**allowed him to delegate organisational tasks and focus on high-level decision-making, though due to**  
**recent circumstances is no longer available to him, meaning that he faces additional challenges in**  
**organising legal documents, meeting deadlines, and managing the overall demands of self-**  
**representation.**

## 8.¬†ECHR & Common‚Äëlaw proportionality.¬†Article‚ÄØ6 guarantees a right of effective access to a court.¬†Where domestic rules (here, automatic strike‚Äëout and indemnity costs) collide with a statutory protection (Breathing‚ÄëSpace) the court must construe and apply them compatibly: Gudanaviciene¬†[2014]¬†EWCA¬†Civ¬†1622; UNISON v‚ÄØLord Chancellor¬†[2017]¬†UKSC¬†51.  
##   
## 9.¬†Overriding Objective (CPR¬†1.1).¬†Granting a brief stay promotes fair, efficient, and cost‚Äëeffective determination.¬†Conversely, allowing the claim to self‚Äëdestruct today would spawn satellite litigation (relief‚Äëfrom‚Äësanctions / professional negligence / potential judicial review), wasting court and party resources.  
##   
## 10.¬†Case‚Äëlaw on statutory moratoria.¬†In Doughty¬†v¬†Wealands¬†[2006]¬†UKHL¬†11 the House of Lords confirmed that where a statute suspends a cause of action or remedy, the court must respect that prohibition absent express contrary words.¬†Regulations‚ÄØ7¬†&‚ÄØ12 are unequivocal.  
##   
## 11.¬†Equality Act precedents.¬†The EAT in Rackham¬†v¬†NHS¬†Professionals¬†(2015) emphasised the ‚Äúanticipatory duty‚Äù to adjust procedure for neuro‚Äëdivergent litigants.¬†The stay sought is a textbook reasonable adjustment: practical, time‚Äëlimited, and cost‚Äëfree.  
##   
## 12.¬†Absence of prejudice to the Defendant.¬†The Defendant already benefits from (i) a global stay of the substantive claim, (ii) security for costs via the unpaid court fee / interim costs order, and (iii) an LCRO.¬†A fortnight‚Äôs pause cannot undermine those protections.  
##   
## 13.¬†Wider public‚Äëinterest dimension.¬†This application raises the interface between the Debt‚ÄëRespite Regulations and civil procedure ‚Äì a point of general importance yet to be considered by an appellate court.¬†Preserving the issue for appeal is desirable.

## 4. PROCEDURAL UNFAIRNESS & OVERRIDING OBJECTIVE  
## 4.1 No Meaningful Opportunity: The new Order was apparently made on the Defendant‚Äôs unilateral initiative. I received no formal notice, no draft to approve, and no hearing to argue against imposing a stay or restricting default judgment. This contravenes:  
## CPR 1.1 (the Overriding Objective), which demands a fair procedure and equal footing for parties‚Äîparticularly a disabled/ unrepresented litigant;  
## Article 6 ECHR, ensuring a right to a fair hearing before significant orders issue.  
## 4.2 Bullet Summary of Key Irregularities:  
## Unilateral Drafting: The Defendant‚Äôs solicitors drew up an order blocking my default judgment, without circulating a draft for my input;  
## Ignoring Default: The Defendant‚Äôs failure to file a Defence was overlooked, contrary to CPR 12‚Äôs mandatory approach;  
## Exclusion of ADHD Concerns: No attempt to tailor directions or deadlines to accommodate my neurodivergent needs;  
## Potential Ex Parte Contact: I have seen no formal application from the Defendant, raising the possibility of behind-the-scenes communications.

## 5. DENTON COMPLIANCE & DEFAULT JUDGMENT ENTITLEMENT  
## Under CPR 12.3, default judgment is nearly ‚Äúautomatic‚Äù where no Defence is filed, unless a recognised bar (like a pending strike-out) applies.  
## The Defendant‚Äôs inaction:  
## Violates the strict time limit in CPR 15.2.  
## Contravenes the ‚Äúculture of compliance‚Äù reaffirmed in Denton and Mitchell.  
## Proper recourse, if they do have a defence, is to file a relief-from-sanctions or set-aside application under CPR 13. This places the burden on them to show a real prospect of success.  
## Instead, the challenged Order preempts my right to default judgment, granting them a procedural windfall for no reason. That is unfair and contrary to the Overriding Objective.

## 6.1 Immediate Risk: If the Order is sealed and enforced now:  
## My application for default judgment is effectively nullified;  
## I am forced into an administrative quagmire (set-aside or appeal), contrary to CPR 12‚Äôs straightforward route.

## 6.3 Ex Parte Necessity: Providing notice could allow the Defendant to seal the Order immediately, defeating my default-judgment position. ## I am writing as Mr. Eastwood's consultant psychiatrist, having known him for a few years in the course  
## of diagnosing his ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder), and subsequent treatment. Most  
## recently, we met to review progress at Schoen Clinic Chelsea on 5 November 2024. The purpose of  
## this letter is to verify his diagnosis for the purpose of his court hearing and outline a range of  
## reasonable adjustments that may be worthy of consideration, in order to achieve a productive hearing  
## for all concerned.  
## There are aspects of Mr. Eastwood's Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) which are likely  
## to present some challenges and directly impact his ability to manage the demands of legal  
## proceedings. Broadly, ADHD is recognised to affect executive functioning, including planning,  
## organisation, time management, and information processing. He is concerned that without  
## reasonable adjustments, there is a risk that he may be unable to fully and fairly participate in these  
## proceedings.  
## Specific adjustments that would assist in engaging with the case more effectively include:  
## - Breaking down complex instructions into smaller, manageable steps, and offering guidance one point  
## at a time  
## - Providing an overview of the hearing at the start, as well as short breaks after each section of the  
## hearing or prior to him making decisions, to assist him in processing the information and participating  
## more effectively  
## - Reminders of his ability to adjourn  
## Please note that in a crisis outside office hours, urgent support can be contacted via your GP, A&E department or local mental health crisis  
## / home treatment team ‚Äì see www.nhs.uk for emergency services near you.  
## For more detailed information regarding medication please see: https://www.choiceandmedication.org/schoenclinicchelsea  
## - Exercising discretion to allow flexibility with deadlines without the additional administrative burden  
## of applying for extensions  
## - Focusing on the substance of his arguments rather than penalising him for any formatting and  
## presentation issues in his written submissions  
## - Allowing him extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings and avoiding rushing responses  
## - Providing clear explanations of legal terms and ensuring he understands important points before  
## moving on  
## - Showing patience in addressing behaviours such as losing focus, becoming easily distracted, or  
## exhibiting impulsive behaviour such as speaking out of turn, and gently reminding him of courtroom  
## protocols where necessary  
## - Allowing flexible timeframes where possible to allow him to stay on task and manage the various  
## demands of the case  
## - Allowing extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings  
## - Simplifying legal instructions and providing them in both verbal and written formats  
## - Allowing him to present his argument with minimal interruptions to help avoid cognitive overload  
## - Breaking longer hearings into shorter, manageable sessions if appropriate  
## I appreciate that these are likely to be aspects of standard practice within your court, but hopefully  
## having them explicitly outlined along with the rationale behind them is helpful in the interest of  
## progressing the case as smoothly as possible. Mr Eastwood reports that for over 10 years, he relied  
## on a Personal Assistant (PA / EA) and other support staff to help manage his professional and personal  
## responsibilities, as an essential part of his compensatory strategies. This administrative support

## Dear Master Kaye  
## I am writing as Mr. Eastwood's consultant psychiatrist, having known him for a few years in the course  
## of diagnosing his ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder), and subsequent treatment. Most  
## recently, we met to review progress at Schoen Clinic Chelsea on 5 November 2024. The purpose of  
## this letter is to verify his diagnosis for the purpose of his court hearing and outline a range of  
## reasonable adjustments that may be worthy of consideration, in order to achieve a productive hearing  
## for all concerned.  
## There are aspects of Mr. Eastwood's Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) which are likely  
## to present some challenges and directly impact his ability to manage the demands of legal  
## proceedings. Broadly, ADHD is recognised to affect executive functioning, including planning,  
## organisation, time management, and information processing. He is concerned that without  
## reasonable adjustments, there is a risk that he may be unable to fully and fairly participate in these  
## proceedings.  
## Specific adjustments that would assist in engaging with the case more effectively include:  
## - Breaking down complex instructions into smaller, manageable steps, and offering guidance one point  
## at a time  
## - Providing an overview of the hearing at the start, as well as short breaks after each section of the  
## hearing or prior to him making decisions, to assist him in processing the information and participating  
## more effectively  
## - Reminders of his ability to adjourn  
## Please note that in a crisis outside office hours, urgent support can be contacted via your GP, A&E department or local mental health crisis  
## / home treatment team ‚Äì see www.nhs.uk for emergency services near you.  
## For more detailed information regarding medication please see: https://www.choiceandmedication.org/schoenclinicchelsea  
## - Exercising discretion to allow flexibility with deadlines without the additional administrative burden  
## of applying for extensions  
## - Focusing on the substance of his arguments rather than penalising him for any formatting and  
## presentation issues in his written submissions  
## - Allowing him extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings and avoiding rushing responses  
## - Providing clear explanations of legal terms and ensuring he understands important points before  
## moving on  
## - Showing patience in addressing behaviours such as losing focus, becoming easily distracted, or  
## exhibiting impulsive behaviour such as speaking out of turn, and gently reminding him of courtroom  
## protocols where necessary  
## - Allowing flexible timeframes where possible to allow him to stay on task and manage the various  
## demands of the case  
## - Allowing extra time to collect his thoughts during hearings  
## - Simplifying legal instructions and providing them in both verbal and written formats  
## - Allowing him to present his argument with minimal interruptions to help avoid cognitive overload  
## - Breaking longer hearings into shorter, manageable sessions if appropriate  
## I appreciate that these are likely to be aspects of standard practice within your court, but hopefully  
## having them explicitly outlined along with the rationale behind them is helpful in the interest of  
## progressing the case as smoothly as possible. Mr Eastwood reports that for over 10 years, he relied  
## on a Personal Assistant (PA / EA) and other support staff to help manage his professional and personal  
## responsibilities, as an essential part of his compensatory strategies. This administrative support  
## allowed him to delegate organisational tasks and focus on high-level decision-making, though due to  
## recent circumstances is no longer available to him, meaning that he faces additional challenges in  
## organising legal documents, meeting deadlines, and managing the overall demands of self-  
## representation.  
## Please do not hesitate to get in touch with any queries.  
## Please note that in a crisis outside office hours, urgent support can be contacted via your GP, A&E department or local mental health crisis  
## / home treatment team ‚Äì see www.nhs.uk for emergency services near you.  
## For more detailed information regarding medication please see: https://www.choiceandmedication.org/schoenclinicchelsea
